Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. A quadratic function \(f\) is defined by \(f(x)=(x-7)(x+3)\).
    1. Without graphing, identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph of \(f\).

Correct! \((7,0)\) and \((-3,0)\). If \(x\) is \(7\), \((7-7)(7+3)\) gives (0,10), which is 0. If \(x\) is -3, \((-3-7)(-3+3)\) gives (-10,0), which is 0.

Try again. Revisit activities 7.10.1 – 7.10.4.

The correct answer is \((7,0)\0 and \((-3,0)\). If \(x\) is 7, \((7-7)(7+3)\) gives 0 10, which is 0. If \(x\) is -3, \((-3-7)(-3+3)\) gives -10 0, which is 0.

    1. Use the standard form of \((x-7)(x+3)\) to identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph of \(f\).

Enter your answer here:

Correct! – 21 The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is \((0,-21)\).

Try again. Revisit activities 7.10.1 – 7.10.4.

The correct answer is – 21. The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is (0,-21).

  1. Answer these questions for the equation \(y=x^2-5x+4\).
    1. What is the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of this equation’s graph?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 4 The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is (0,4).

Try again. Revisit activities 7.10.2 and 7.10.3.

The correct answer is 4. The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is \((0,4)\).

    1. An equivalent way to write this equation is \(y=(x-4)(x-1)\). What are the \(x\)-intercepts of this equation’s graph?

Correct! \((1,0)\) and \((4,0)\) . If \(x\) is 1, \((1-4)(1-1)\) gives \((-3) (0)\) which is 0. If \(x\) is 4, \((4-4)(4-1)\) gives \((0) (3)\) which is 0.

Try again. Revisit activities 7.10.2 and 7.10.3.

The correct answer is \((1,0)\) and \((4,0)\). If \(x\) is 1, \((1-4)(1-1)\) gives \((-3) (0)\) which is 0. If \(x\) is 4, \((4-4)(4-1)\) gives \((0) (3)\) which is 0.

  1. Noah said that if we graph \(y=(x-1)(x+6)\), the \(x\)-intercepts will be at \((1,0)\) and \((-6,0)\). Is Noah correct?

Correct! We can check by substituting 1 for \(x\) and -6 for \(x\) and see if they produce an output of 0. If \(x\) is 1, \((1-1)(1+6)\) gives (0)(7), which is 0. If \(x\) is – 6, \((-6-1)(-6+6)\) gives (-7)(0), which is 0.

Try again. Revisit activities 7.10.2 – 7.10.4.

The correct answer is Yes. We can check by substituting 1 for \(x\) and – 6 for \(x\) and see if they produce an output of 0. If \(x\) is 1, \((1-1)(1+6)\) gives (0)(7), which is 0. If \(x\) is – 6, \((-6-1)(-6+6)\) gives (-7)(0), which is 0.

  1. Select two \(x\)-intercepts of this graph.

Correct! The graph crosses the \(x\)-axis at \((-1,0)\) and \((3,0)\).

Try again. Revisit activities 7.10.2 and 7.10.3.

The correct answer is – 1 and 3.

  1. Use the standard form of \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\) to identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Correct!

Try again. Revisit activity 7.10.4.

The correct answer is 8.
